The battery life is just out of the world. It is like a camel in the desert without water- it can go on and on and on.What's my biggest gripe? Skype. I use it pretty often and it is the choice of most when it comes to video calling, across the world. The alternative offered is Hangout video calling. But as a medium of communication this is still to catch on and this is the most restrictive feature of the Chromebook. Akin to Skype Out, Hangouts also provides the facility to call phones and mobiles by buying credit- works across the world and not only specific countries (the purchasing of the credit).Of course the requirement of being on line for most of the tasks is also restrictive but then that is a given and known when you buy the Chromebook.Two other products which I have figured out are not available but might be high use apps are Spotify and Picasa. The latter is surprising considering it is from Google, but I think the objective is to push everyone onto Google+ Photos.Sound is excellent. Has a small bass and is more than adequate.Overall- this (and any Chromebook) can not be your primary PC/laptop. But is a must get for easy access, browsing and great battery life. Would be a great gift and also great entry level notebook for kids.

Reviews.Title: ACE'S HIGH
Reviews.Author: IVAN ITURRALDE
Reviews.Content: This was my first experience with a Chrome Book as my wife wanted a secondary laptop just to browse. For the money your paying, you can't ask for more. Boots up fast, great battery life, light & compact just throw it in the bag and take it the park or beach it feels sturdy enough. This Chromebook can definitely survive high-school or college life, parents take note.

Reviews.Title: Love it
Reviews.Author: Burke Fitness, LLC
Reviews.Content: I have really liked my Acer C720 Chromebook. Since I purchased it, I have not once picked up my old laptop or used my desktop. The chrome extensions and applications seem to cover all that I need, which includes listening to music, email, gmail, photo editing, video editing, web surfing, bill pay, business finances managing, word, excel, and powerpoint publication (whether through Google Docs, or the new Office Apps Chrome extension).I also have Chrome Remote Desktop activated, so if I do need to access my other computers, I have the ability from anywhere I am as long as I have WIFI.All in all, it's a great machine for me.

Reviews.Title: Great Christmas gift, she loves it.
Reviews.Author: Lorentsen
Reviews.Content: My fiancee had mentioned to me at different times she wanted a netbook type of computer, she wanted something small enough that wouldn't take up too much kitchen table space and yet large enough for comfortable viewing.With so many different netbooks on the market, it was a hard choice. Knowing she likes using Google Chrome, Gmail and other Google products, I decided to focus on a Google oriented computer. Chromebook and I'm glad I did. She loves it.The Chromebook is perfect in size,  you feel like you're using a laptop without the chunkiness. The bootup is extremely fast, turn it on and you're ready to go in seconds. The graphics and sound quality are fine for watching movies or listening to music.One feature she liked, you can set the touch pad to scroll with two fingers, making for easy web browsing. For applications, Google has numerous additional applications that can be used on the Chromebook.There is a decent amount of space to store personal files on the Chromebook, it is also compatible with external USB drives and SD cards if you need more space. You do not have to use Google Drive, my fiancee uses a 64GB SDXC card for extra storage.As for durability, durability is fine for everyday normal use. If you have a habit of dropping computers, don't blame the product if you break it, instead buy a laptop designed for handling abuse.A lot of the complaints about this Chromebook are clearly from people who did not bother to take the time to read the product description. The product description is accurate, it tells you exactly what this device is meant for.This is a *web based computer designed around Google* and with that in mind, the Chromebook is worth every penny for what it is designed for.

Reviews.Title: Great laptop, great price
Reviews.Author: Hexydes
Reviews.Content: I'll preface this by saying that I've used the HP 11 and Samsung Series 3  Chromebooks for a few weeks each. The C720 is better in some ways than the HP 11, worse in others. It however beats the Samsung Series 3 in almost every way possible. It's better than the HP 11 in that the processor is MUCH faster. Browsing through tabs and using more intensive websites is a much better experience than on the HP 11. However, the screen and form-factor of the HP 11 are, in my opinion, much better than the C720.Overall though, this is a great laptop. Had they simply put a little more thought into the design, and used an IPS display (which I would be willing to pay a total of $50 extra for), they'd have had a runaway hit. As such though, this is still a great laptop, and if you're looking for a solid Chromebook, you won't be disappointed with this one.

Reviews.Title: Wow
Reviews.Author: crazygirl "kelli"
Reviews.Content: Wow this has got to be the best bang for the buck. I've never been a very computer literate, but dealing with my new Acer, has been a very awesome experience. I have two kindle books that I kind of used to help me with a general overview. This is so different in a great way. I can"t believe the boot time on this machine. To me it seems more like 4 seconds rather than the stated 7. People have mentioned the keyboard feeling flimsy but I think it suits me just fine. Sounds pretty good with the Dre beats.....sound beats the heck out of my Sony xperia z and kindle fire 7 HD 2012. Much louder and for199.00 that was a pleasant surprise. Feels solid, not cheap at all. I'm still trying to get this app-extension thing figured out and the productivity apps? are so impressive. I'm happier than a pig in, well you know where I am going. Out of stock right now at Amazon and I can see why. This thing is THE BOMB!!!!!!

Reviews.Title: Big functionality in a tiny fast package!
Reviews.Author: TomBob
Reviews.Content: you can keep Windows 8.  This is everything I need in a fast little package.  I also own a MAC desktop, I Pad mini. They are feeling somewhat neglected since the arrival of my Acer Chromebook.

Reviews.Title: Great Unit
Reviews.Author: Jerry
Reviews.Content: In order to test this unit right out of the box, I attached an HDMI cable and plugged it into a 32" TV.  I also plugged in a Logitech wireless mouse and key board.  Then I turned it in.  One upgrade later it was working like a champ (Total less than a minute).  From then on 10 seconds or less.  No noise.  Both my wife and I have logins.  Just click on your name, put in your Google password and there you are.  Amazing unit.  It just sits there, quietly.  Runs every web page, Netflix, Hulu, Amazon.  We have concentrated on doing everything on the cloud.  My wife does volunteer accounting and membership list work for the county library.  Fortunately, they are smart enough to use Google docs and spreadsheets (BTW-why would you buy Microsoft office when Google Docs is Free?).This is the best unit you can possibly buy-IF you do not need programs  For example, I have a software program for converting VHS to DVD. Can't use it.  I also have a full software program for our printer so I can scan, etc.  Can't use it, although the Chromebook prints to the printer fine.  I also am using Turbotax and Quicken for the last time.  Once I change to on-line that will not be a problem.  Oddest yet, I have Dish network with the Sling Player built in.  Won't work???  The sling works fine on my computer, tablet and even phone, but not on the Chromebook.  I am assuming (hoping) that will be fixed.  We are snowbirds and spend 2 1/2 months in the desert.  DishAnywhere is a godsend for us.If you are buying a second computer, or do not need programs, a Chromebook is the best possible solution.  If you want a computer for your parents and want to be able to communicate without worrying about Microsoft or viruses, this is the one.  You must use Hangouts (no Skype) for webcam communication

Reviews.Title: Works great - IF its what you need.
Reviews.Author: Kayhold
Reviews.Content: My husband and I are 2 very very different creatures. I use my laptop to watch TV, movies or browse the web.He uses his to listen, organize music, and reload his ipod and in general manage his 250 gigs of music.While this Chromebook is great for what I need, its not at all great for my husband, who it was bought for.Now, I thought "Oh, it has bluetooth, he should have no problem with his iPod!" but that wasn't the case. It appears the bluetooth is for things like speakers, and not file transfers. They would not pair up and some research showed it wasn't going to happen.I did plug his ipod directly into a USB port, and I could access the ipod but not like we wanted.Downloading iTunes was also not happening.So, while I would have just used Google Music, my husband is not willing to change his ways, ha! The free Google Music would only let him move 20,000 songs which is about half of what he owns.So, unfortunately we will be returning it for a Windows 8 netbook, but I'm considering buying my own Chromebook.

Reviews.Title: Great notebook for student or just anybody!
Reviews.Author: Omid Barat
Reviews.Content: I bought this chromebook knowing exactly what I am getting into.  People, this is a Chromebook! Not a laptop or a wannabe-laptop!  You can only access the Chrome browser, nothing else.I was blown away by the speed and battery life of this machine.  I also really like the buttons on the top, this doesn't have the F1 - F12 buttson, this has buttons with graphics as to what they do.  Very useful.  I also love  what Google did with the touchpad: 2 Finger scroll, 2 finger snap from right to left goes back, and left to right is forward.  3 Finger snap to either direction switches from one tab to the other, depending on the direction you go.I also love the full screen mode, and the keyboard itself.  I have been using mine for about a week now and am very happy with the battery life, and the overall feel and ease of use of the ChromeOS.  I have been holding it on my lap and hardly feel any heat after HOURS of heavy usage (youtube videos, documents and such.)The main reason I bought this was because I will start a software engineering position soon and wanted to catch up my Java programming skills.  Unfortunately, there is no way to run a traditional IDE like Netbeans or Eclipse on ChromeOS. I tried some of the cloud-based IDE and didn't like it.  The good news is that putting a flavored linux operating system called ChruBuntu is a PIECE OF CAKE.So when I need to do some programming, I switch to Linux and start up Eclipse, it works great!As for performance, I tend to browse or work with at most 5 tabs, and so far, I am very satisfied.Great job Google/Acer!!!  I look forward to buying the next gen!

Reviews.Title: Bought it, tried it, disliked it... not the product but the Cloud concept
Reviews.Author: Flashfox
Reviews.Content: Someone made a valid point. The 3-star wasn't merited as the issue is not with the C720 but with my expectations. So as a product, it does what it is supposed to do and it does it well. It's fast, light and easy to use. I don't give it a 5-star as that would be for the touch-screen version.My personal issues are that I mistakenly got the non-touchscreen version but in retrospect, it was a waste of money for me. Requiring "The Cloud" for almost everything is a serious handicap if you are in an area where there is no Wi-Fi. I had to tether this Chromebook to my phone many times. The product itself is OK but the "Cloud" concept it too restrictive for me.

Reviews.Title: This is one happy camper...
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Imagine a laptop that will not only NOT SLOW DOWN over time but that will actually SPEED UP!There is your Acer Chromebook for you, a dream come true...I have been buying ever more @powerful@ laptops for some two decades and the scenario has always been the same: a two week, perhaps, @honeymoon@ during which my computer works fine, and then... a slow and progressive downfall.This laptop is different in that it does not get viruses - just like your phone.The screen is extremely crappy but what the heck: this is a $200.00 laptop!In closing, I must address the question of the supposed inability of this laptop to do serious work.Unless you are a @developper@ - and I<m pretty sure there must be Google apps to do that too - this laptop has all you need.The number of Google apps is growing by the day and is already quite sufficient to whet your appetite...

Reviews.Title: Best laptop to stay productive!
Reviews.Author: J. Daniel Spratlin
Reviews.Content: I bought the Acer C720 to have something lighter to carry around. I have a Dell Windows laptop that's has incredible specs; however, I don't find myself ever using it to its maximum capabilities. So why should I drag around 6.5 lbs with me all day? The Acer C720 is incredibly light and it's much thinner than it appears in the pictures. The build is very nice for a $199 laptop. It uses a sturdy matte colored plastic which I actually find rather attractive. It doesn't look toy-like.The screen is something that many people have complained about but I find it perfectly satisfactory. The resolution is good enough for the size of the screen and it's plenty bright to be used in sunlight especially since it's a matte display. The keyboard is nicely spaced and the keys feel okay at best. The keys are very shallow which I don't particularly like but I can understand why they had to do that. It takes a little bit of time to get used to but after a day's use, the keyboard should feel fine. My WPM fell about 10 from my average 85-90 WPM on a desktop keyboard but after several days, I'm starting to get back up to that range. The trackpad is really nice. It has a nice smooth texture and it's responsive. I don't know what some of the other review have been saying about it being loose. Mine is definitely sturdy. It does make a loud click but if you turn on "tap to click" you'll only actually have to make a loud click when you have to grab and drag something.I bought this laptop to primarily use out and about for work so it was very important for me to have it open my PDFs. I put my PDF files on the 16gb hard drive and they open right up with the Chrome PDF viewer. Perfect! All of my documents, music, and photos were already in the Google cloud so as soon as I turned the laptop on, everything was ready to be viewed.The battery is rather amazing as well considering how light this laptop is. The machine came with no power. Once I plugged it in, it took just over an hour to charge. On my first charge, I've managed to get just under 9 hours! Wow! My usage was pretty light though. Primarily opening up books, reading news, typing two emails, and watching a couple of youtube videos. Still, that's an awesome battery life.In terms of Chrome OS, I think it has a perfect balance between simplicity and functionality. Sure, it can't run Photoshop or autoCAD, but I think the majority of people don't use those programs. I, personally, don't need anything more than what Chrome OS offers. If you really need some kind of editing tool, the Chrome Store has replacement apps that can get the job done. You just have to look for those apps or just Google search for them.Speed on this little guy is incredible! I can't believe that a $199 machine can work this quickly. Pages load up almost instantly and that includes videos. In terms of browser performance, the Acer beats my Windows laptop (which has a Core i7, 8gb ram, and a SSD). I don't know how Google accomplished this but it's truly incredible. I think the 4gb model is overkill. This 2gb model has not slowed on me. I use a max of about 10 tabs. The laptop never lags or skips a beat with that many open. I personally don't use more than that at any one time; however, I've heard that this thing can handle up to 20 tabs without slowing down. I can't imagine how many you'd need to open for the 4gb model to slow down.In general, this is a 5 star machine. If you're looking for a productivity machine that can entertain you during breaks, then look no further. This is the one!

Reviews.Title: All it's cracked up to be, but not much more
Reviews.Author: Simon Grey
Reviews.Content: Before I bought this, I bought a Toshiba Satellite 15634 because I needed a cheap laptop to complement my Kindle Fire HDX (You know, Flash, keyboard, MS Office, etc., plus the capability to cast to Chromecast.) I returned that since it lagged terribly streaming videos, and was just too flimsy. Then I thought I'd try a chromebook, being apprehensive about the OS. I have since come to love this notebook. In fact, I was sold on the set up, before I even got to the desktop. I opened the lid and it immediately asked for the password to my WIFI, and within seconds, I was up and running. It's light and fast and at $200, it beats all expectations. The web based word processor and spreadsheet are plenty sufficient for my needs. It still lags when streaming HBOGO, but I can cast it to my TV via the Chromecast with no issues (well, other than the fact that if you navigate away from the page you're on, you lose the controls, or I haven't figured out how to get them back yet.) All in all, I find this a delightful little tool on the coffee table, not the least for the fact that I don't have to give up my Tablet everytime someone wants to "check something real quick." I just toss them chromebook.

Reviews.Title: Does what I need it to do
Reviews.Author: NR
Reviews.Content: I use this for schooling since I am taking all of my classes online. Startup is fast, works smooth. Google drive took some time for me to get used to, but the printer I have can print off of Google drive, which is very nice. The battery last a very long time, so when research papers are being typed up, I don't have to worry about the battery dying on me in a few hours. I don't need it for games, I built my own PC for that. It's very lightweight and easy to carry in a backpack. I coupled it with a 64 GB flashdrive to hold all of my documents and no problems. I have had it freeze up on me a couple of times since I bought it, and holding the power button for an extended amount of time (~20 seconds) resets it, and it works fine again. Nice budget friendly for those looking for something to type papers, check Facebook, surf YouTube, and check e-mail.

Reviews.Title: Excellent for web surfing, email, and and streaming videos
Reviews.Author: CarportMechanic
Reviews.Content: I purchased this Chromebook specifically to surf the web, read and answer emails, and watch streaming videos (netflix, HBOgo, you tube, etc.).  It works really well for everything.  One feature I really like is that when you open the lid, it is immediately connected to wifi and you don't have to wait for it to connect as you often have to do with PCs.  It really fits the bill for my needs.  It's small and thin and light and very portable.  Excellent battery life too.  Overall very pleased and happy with this purchase.

Reviews.Title: Love, love it!
Reviews.Author: Summer "Summertimealways"
Reviews.Content: We have never had a laptop before, and after reading many reviews,I decided on this one since I needed something affordable. My husbandstruggles to read on a cell phone, and he doesn't like tablets, so I got himthis. He told me to order another one because our teenagers fight over it.This has been the go to computer and I like that because everyone leavesme alone now on my computer.

Reviews.Title: My First Chromebook
Reviews.Author: biz56
Reviews.Content: Studied all the models for weeks.  Shouldn't have waited so long.  Love it, and a terrific value at that.  Use it primarily for surfing and e-mail at home and while traveling in airports, planes, hotels, etc, anywhere with wifi.  Thought hard about the larger size, but 11.6 inches is fine for my uses and the light weight makes it great for a lap computer and don't have to prop it up like a tablet. Battery life at about 4 hours is not as advertised, but it charges fast.  2 meg memory has not been a problem for me.  New models coming out soon and deserve a look, but you can't go wrong with this one for $199.

Reviews.Title: Finally an easy to use computer
Reviews.Author: William Litherland
Reviews.Content: I use a lot of computers in my work doing accounting and tax work. When I get hoe I have wanted an easy to navigate to check personal emails and do some of the online courses that are available. This is the solution. It boots up instantly and puts you on the internet in under 7 seconds! It doesn't need virus protection as everything is in the cloud. The screen size is just right to balance on my lap. I haven't tackled the printer issue but I have another computer that I can print out of if necessary. My wife also bought and she is just as pleased as I am.

Reviews.Title: Great refurb, great price
Reviews.Author: F. Hall
Reviews.Content: The Chromebook is great and really responsive.  The only thing you need to be aware of is it needs an Internet connection to be useful.  Also, for a refurb, you could never tell the difference from a new machine....no marks or scratches anywhere that I could find.

Reviews.Title: I love it!
Reviews.Author: bebelov
Reviews.Content: The Acer C720 Chromebook is exactly what I needed.  It starts up immediately and lets you check your emails, surf the web and run your favorite apps in no time at all.  I chose this to save the life of my laptop which was taking longer and longer to boot up and shut down.  Now I can check email, Facebook or anything else even when I only have a few minutes to spare.  And it is so light and portable, I can take it anywhere.  I highly recommend this Chromebook!

Reviews.Title: A Most Surprising Experience!
Reviews.Author: Sirzune
Reviews.Content: Is the concept of cloud-computing something for you? Let's see...Since receiving the Acer Chromebook C720-2848 several days ago, I've come away with a brand new perspective on the Chrome operating system. Here's my take on it and why, if your needs aren't completely dependent on Windows, this may be just the right call for you.First, what is a Chromebook? It is a laptop with its own system that relies on everything Google, and runs the operating system "Chrome OS".  Chrome OS does not allow for "programs" to be run in the manner that Windows or Mac does. It is almost fully browser-dependent (but not to the extreme that you can't use the computer without an internet connection). You run "programs" in the Chrome browser, and they run quickly and efficiently, with hardly any hesitation. Unlike that of Windows' program launching, Chrome OS is nearly immediate and glorious in its ability to do your bidding.The first thing you will note about the system is that it boots in under 7 seconds so that you can come from a cold start to having logged-in and ready for work or play. I am used to having my Windows 7 installation tweaked for high performance, but the Chrome OS needs no help there.  A few things before I really get into it should be noted:There is no firewall to configure; no need for virus protection; system is automatically updated without bother, and has an SSD (solid state drive for virtually noiseless computing), and can run up to 8 to 9 hours on one charge.  The OS requires no license validation and can be re-installed quickly if need be. Sounds intriguing? Stick around and hold on to your wig because this thing will flip it!This particular model is the C720-2848, at $200, a revamping of the older C710.  The Intel Celeron Haswell architecture brain that runs it is quite faster than the prior model, C710's Celeron brain, and comes with either 2GB of DDR3 ram or, for more handling power, 4GB, for $50 more. It appears for most users that is over-kill, as most won't have more that 10 to 12 windows running at the same time. My model is capable of having several Youtube videos playing, and several other windows open, with no adverse hit in performance. Should you choose to try a Chromebook, don't pick the older model, regardless of sales discount inducement.When you boot into your Chromebook you are met with a desktop, similar to a Windows PC, but there are no icons on the desktop. Instead, there is a sidebar where you chose which program you wish to use. You want to surf, you click the Chrome icon, and you are quickly sent off to the internet. There is also an apps icon that you click in order to see all of your applications that are available to you. These applications can be downloaded (downloaded here means: the shortcut to the application that will play in the Chrome browser) from the Chrome Store. You can build quite an impressive amount of useful apps for work or play and delete them (getting rid of the shortcut to the application) as you see fit. An example of a utility app is Screencastify, a screen video recorder that can record all you do with or without sound. You can also capture video with the webcam. Snagit, from Techsmith, is another useful app for screen recording or snapping shots of anything that you want on any page you go to.  Another useful application is Clearly, an app that rids pages of all extraneous litter, leaving only text so that you can read or save it.  There is a growing lineup of games that can be played via the browser as well, one of which is still popular, Angry Birds. You won't be able to play more demanding games, but this is not a gaming computer. As more and more users Skype now than ever before, Chromebook users are not as fortunate. But you can use Google Hangout for calls and video chatting. All sorts of utility apps and more are populating the Chrome Store, so this is just the beginning of what may turn out to be a most welcome and fast-growing app market for your Chromebook.The Chromebook can not accept printers via usb (remember: you can't install programs), but you can wirelessly print via Google Cloud Print to your printer as long as you have a printer that is capable of cloud printing. Nearly all printers for just under $100 have this feature today.Typing on the keyboard was an unexpected pleasure, as I have never been able to type comfortably with any laptop I've ever used. The touch pad is responsive and utilizes the familiar one finger mouse move, and two and three finger gestures, the latter being for scrolling back and forth through the open windows. You can plug in a usb or wireless mouse and keyboard, but you probably won't need to.As for music play, the speakers for a low-cost computer as this sound great.  There's appreciable loudness with hardly any noticeable shrill at very 80% volume. The is some slight bass, not heavy and shouldn't be expected on this laptop.  The bluetooth works with newer versions and is backwards compatible with bluetooth 2.0 and up.For light users of Microsoft Office, Google Docs takes over the job. It will read, write and edit the documents. Just don't expect it to be on par with its very expensive brotheren.This model comes with 16 GB (there is a 32 GB SSD --Solid State Drive-- version available) of drive storage and can be supplemented with Google Drive cloud storage (free) for additional storage. You can also slip in an SD card up to 64 GB for .PDF files, documents of all extensions, movies, pictures and music.As for entertainment, Youtube and Netflix is clear and never stutters. Watching movies one SD card on the matte-finish 11.5 " screen is better than expected for such a low priced laptop. No complaints here.There's an HDMI out port and one USB 3.0 and one USB 2.0 port, headphone/mic input.At just 2.7 lbs, this laptop is not cumbersome and stays very cool even after hours of play. I am writing this document on it and I feel quite comfortable doing it. I can't say that about any laptop I've used in the past. I've seen the best of laptops come my way for repair, and not once was I enthralled by the keyboard.  I love this keyboard!When you are not connected to the internet, you can still enjoy your Chromebook to some extent.  You can still write documents, read and write email (for sending later), play one of many free games, read a book or just settle in for a good old movie.  It isn't as crippled as Microsoft's damning commercial makes it out to be, is it?The question now, is: Is this for you? If you aren't a lover of Google's self-contained system and are really dependent on specialized programs, then you probably won't find much to like about it. But if you are all things Google and have no need for heavy, specialized programs like Photoshop, or intensive music production software, heavy 3-D gaming and the total Microsoft Office experience, welcome to the next thing in computing!By Eddie T

Reviews.Title: Chromebook
Reviews.Author: ChesterHartman
Reviews.Content: For $199 the computer is a miracle. What more can I say? The question is though, can I count on it over time.

Reviews.Title: I LUV IT
Reviews.Author: Kindle Customer
Reviews.Content: I just got it but lack of set up and the portability is great. It surfs the internet super fast. I am very happy. I am writing this review for all the people who wrote reviews and helped me make my decision. If you are not a super technical programmer, this computer should be just fine. I recently went back to school and I think computer works great for my needs. It loads up really fast and updates instantly. I am never buying another windows product again.

Reviews.Title: Excellent product
Reviews.Author: Adrià Vilanova Martínez
Reviews.Content: This laptop accomplished all my expectations. I like a lot that it boots in 7 seconds, because it's magic! You are ready to work in so little time... Also, it is fast and the keyboard it's pretty soft, I like it. Works perfectly for the moment.Great computer if you want to browse the web!

Reviews.Title: Acer C720 Chromebook first time owner
Reviews.Author: HLEStringman "hlestringman"
Reviews.Content: Just got this unit. Took about 10 min to set it up. So far it looks to be just what we need for a simple to operate machine. So much of what we do is on the internet, it made sense to try this out. The computer itself appears to be well-made and feels sturdy, not flimsy. The setup was easy and the way a PC should be.

Reviews.Title: Does enough for what I need
Reviews.Author: K. Bystrom
Reviews.Content: I bought this to replace an aging tablet and a broken MacBook Pro.  I wanted something that I would almost only use for quick online tasks or surfing while watching TV.  This really fits the bill.  The start up time with the solid state drive and Chrome OS is sensational.  I used to be apprehensive to use a computer for any quick, menial tasks, but now I just reach from my Acer.  There are some items that take some getting use to.I have run into issues with Citrix because my company doesn't have the latest and greatest that comes with the HTML5 version.  The Chrome OS seems to lack some basic settings that I would like to be able to change.  For example, the Acer will turn on whenever you lift the screen.  It makes sense to do so, but it did take me some time to get used to it when I was just looking to clean the screen or keyboard.  And finally, as I am sure you know, the Chrome OS doesn't have the ability to install programs outside of the Chrome browser.  I knew this going in, but there have been a few times that I wish the OS could at least run very simple programs in an emulated environment.The Acer C720 looks stylish and isn't very flashy.  The keyboard feels a bit cheap compared to any other I have used, but you get what you paid for.  I was actually surprised to find a full-sized HDMI port that easily allows the computer to display on an external display like a monitor or HDTV.  I have actually used that feature more than any other, but having two USB ports that are on EITHER side of the computer is also great.It's exciting to use Chrome OS and the Acer C720.  Google releases new updates to Chrome OS regularly that bring new features and abilities and more and more developers are creating apps that are specific to the OS.

Reviews.Title: Great purchase!
Reviews.Author: Andrea Casnellie
Reviews.Content: I bought this for my daughter for her birthday. She needs a basic, simple book with cloud storage and google apps for school, browsing the internet and social media sites. It is cute, portable, and serves its purpose. I hope she can make it last throughout her school years.

Reviews.Title: Perfect if you have a steady Internet connection.
Reviews.Author: Chris B. "Chris"
Reviews.Content: I own a MacBook Pro, and this little Acer Chromebook quickly won my heart. It is fast, reliable, and functional––if you have a steady Internet connection. If you are reading reviews for Chromebooks, you already know that they are not much good without an Internet connection. This is true, but for the price--how can you afford not to buy one?

Reviews.Title: Use it all the time
Reviews.Author: Janis M Paquette
Reviews.Content: I bought thiis Chromebook specifically for travel, as it's small enough that you don't have to take it out when going through airport security.  But now it's the ONLY computer I use!  It's got a full size keyboard, it's light, the battery holds up a really long time, no worries about getting viruses and it's so fast.....no waitng for long boot-ups.  Love love love it!

Reviews.Title: Great, but Noisy
Reviews.Author: Jared
Reviews.Content: Good screen, keyboard and track-pad and really lightweight.I love everything about the computer except the noise.The noise is a very high pitch sound that kind of sounds like it could be the fan, but everyone on the internet seem to agree that it is coil whine, which cannot be fixed.  It's usually not bad, but if the room you are in is quite it can be pretty annoying and distracting for others around you.

Reviews.Title: Great Chromebook!
Reviews.Author: Max Power
Reviews.Content: I bought this for my Dad to replace his old Windows XP desktop. All he does is email and surf he web. This is perfect! Great price and does what it says.

Reviews.Title: Best Chromebook I have owned
Reviews.Author: Kyle Salewski "Kyle Salewski"
Reviews.Content: I have previously owned the CR-48 and the Acer C710. They were both great machines but this one is so much lighter, snappier, and just works great. I use it as my daily driver and it lasts the entire day. I would definitely recommend this for anyone who needs to write documents, listen to music, watch videos, online shop, and use social media.

Reviews.Title: Satisfied customer
Reviews.Author: sanderella
Reviews.Content: It is very reliable and high functioning for the price!!  Boots quickly, lightweight and long battery life compared to c710.  Love it

Reviews.Title: Pleasant surprise
Reviews.Author: RC65
Reviews.Content: A Chromebook does not do everything a laptop can, but it does 90% of what most people use a laptop for.  Specifically, what it does, and does very well, is surf the internet.  It does this faster than any computer I've used.  It boots up in less than 7 seconds, also much faster than other computers I've used.  It has a battery life that easily lasts over 6 hours, and it also recharges incredibly fast.  Finally, it is much lighter and more portable than a laptop.  While it looks like the old "netbooks", this product is many times superior to those outdated, balky computers.  Amazingly, this product accomplishes all this magic for what I consider to be the best bang for the buck available in computers today ($200). I also own a desktop and a Kindle Fire, but this little computer has become the machine of choice for 90% of my computer time.  In summary, I have a love/hate relationship with most computers, so far with this machine it's all love.

Reviews.Title: Great for a student or anyone on-the-go!
Reviews.Author: Michael
Reviews.Content: For the money, the Acer C720 (2GB) isn't just one of the best Chromebook on the market, it's one of the better cheap laptops on the market. For $199 at the time of my purchase, I could not be happier with what I got for my money. This 11.6" laptop is great on battery life, has stellar performance, and houses a sleek and portable form factor. Chrome OS is limited to some, but with a constant internet connection and a computer at home that you can remote desktop to (not entirely necessary), there isn't much you can't do with a Chromebook. The dual-core Intel Celeron (Haswell) CPU inside isn't power hungry, it doesn't put out much heat at all, and it powers Chrome OS like a boss. The C720 also carries 2GBs of RAM, which is plenty for most of what you'll be doing inside of Chrome. You won't have any stuttering or lag with multiple tabs open in Chrome, a video playing or music in the background while blogging on social media. At the time of this review I currently have 6 tabs open, including a livestream on Twitch.tv, and there is no lag whatsoever. Battery life is also fantastic. With social media, email, music, and word processing, you can expect anywhere from 7 - 9 hours with the C720, slightly less if constantly streaming video. I had a day where I unplugged the laptop at 7am, used it for notes and videos through school till around noon, then used it all day at work researching tech and playing videos; I ended the day at 10pm with around 49% battery, I then proceeded to use the laptop most of the next day at home before it finally dying around 3pm. So you can expect to get through a whole day with this Chromebook. Another additional benefit is USB 3.0. There is 1 on this laptop, as well as a single USB 2.0 port on the other side of the laptop. You also have full HDMI out for running an extra HDMI enabled monitor/tv. This greatly improves functionality if you enjoy having multiple displays. It's lightweight, portable, looks great and the build quality is superb for a sub $200 laptop, but there are a couple downsides. The original carried a full-size SD card slot (when inserted, the card would be flush with the laptop, making portable storage easy), the C720 lacks this, and only carries a half-depth SD card slot, minor downside. Also, there are no function keys as well as no caps lock key, like the original. I would like to be able to ALT-F4 out of Chrome, instead I have to CTRL-W to close each tab/window individually. The screen is 11.6" and has a resolution of 1333x768, which is just fine for a 11" laptop. Viewing angles and color reproduction wasn't the best, but you won't have many complaints sitting in front of the laptop for a few hours. Another downfall out of the box was the keyboard, the keys were shallow but well spaced. After a couple days of use I got completely used to this and am now typing this review on the C720 at 60+ WPM.To conclude, if you're on a budget looking for a laptop, already live inside of Google's ecosystem or are okay with living in the cloud (no classic Windows applications/limited storage), then this laptop will serve you well.The C720 has the best battery life for a Chromebook on the market, other than Dell's Chromebook 11 ($100 more than the C720 at the time of this review),which only carries a couple hours of battery life over the Acer here. Other than that, you won't find better performance, battery life and a simple, utilitarian design in any other sub $200 laptop.Pros:PerformanceBattery lifePortabilityLoud speakersGood trackpad with easy-to-use gesturesCons:Screen viewing angles and colorsLack of caps lock key and F4 key. (Search key can be swapped with Caps lock in settings)Keys are a bit shallow and hard to use at firstIf you reading this feel I didn't cover some aspect of the laptop, feel free to ask a question on this review, I'm very active in replying to Amazon questions. Thanks!

Reviews.Title: Amazing little machine, and a steal at this price
Reviews.Author: Michael
Reviews.Content: I bought this to use as a Linux laptop running Ubuntu via the ChrUbuntu installer, but honestly, for what most people use a laptop for, ChromeOS works great.  Full access to the real web, no mobile site BS, and a full size keyboard are so much nicer than touch typing on glass, or a cramped expensive Bluetooth keyboard.I love the fit and finish.  Solidly built.  No creaks or squeaks.  It's just heavy enough to feel expensive, but not enough to tire you out.  Excellent battery life.  Very portable size.  Intuitive trackpad gestures make mouse interactions work almost as well as a real mouse.The only real knock I can find against it is the display.  Good viewing angles are really tight, and just a few degrees up or down will wash all of the colors out.If you're a power user, you can partition the drive in half, and dual-boot ChromeOS and Linux for a complete laptop experience without the Windows tax.  I can even install Steam and play my indie games on the go.  Very happy with my purchase!

Reviews.Title: Who Needs Microsoft XP?
Reviews.Author: Carl Gluck
Reviews.Content: Ok, I know I'm overstating my case with the remark title. But really, I was perturbed with Microsoft for abruptly pulling the plug on XP. Suddenly I was expected to replace my laptop and the software on it - an expense of at least $1500 to $2000. And why? Because Microsoft got lazy? Windows 8 is horrible. I surely don't want to replace XP with that! So I decided to try a less expensive solution, if only for fun. And Wow! What an improvement! all for $250 (I bought the 32 GB version and a carrying case).At first I was a little less than enthused because after all - the Chromebook is just a glorified browser, right? Wrong! I discovered it is very easy to install a full blown version of Ubuntu Linux with all the bells and whistles - and it doesn't upset the default version of the Chromebook at all. Take that Microsoft!Linux is free. Google software is free. Web storage is free. And the new Acer Chromebook is amazing! 10 seconds from stop to online! Can't beat that. And the battery life is amazing. While this approach may not be for someone who doesn't care for computers or a big learning curve, it is a great approach for someone who has more brains than money.The C720 is fantastic. The processing speed and utility are great. And it is half the size and half the weight of my old laptop. What's not to like?Goodbye Microsoft. Hello new world. And so it goes...

Reviews.Title: Why would you buy the C720 when the Samsung 2's are about to hit?  You might be surprised...
Reviews.Author: Tim Byers
Reviews.Content: Believe it or not, on the same day I learned that the new Samsung Chromebook 2's would be released on April 28, I went ahead and bought the Acer C720.  Why?  First of all, Chromebooks have been interesting to me for a long time, but I'm not an early adopter.  I tried an Android Transformer tablet/keyboard last summer and recently work gave us Windows 8 tablet/laptops. My profile is a tinkerer--and a cheap one at that.  I have a Roku and Chromecast, I mess around with XBMC, and I try to stretch all my tech dollars.  I wanted a simple, lightweight, mobile device with a keyboard--something handy for surfing on the couch, stashing it away in a backpack and riding the bike to my local coffee shop for some writing.  The other reviews and numerous Youtubes on this unit are consistently very good.  What finally snagged me was the XP laptop trade-in deal offered by a local retailer and suggested by an article on CNET, which enabled me to bring this home at half-price.Playing with it for a night and a morning (normal Chrome apps, Outlook.com (just to see if I could still use Microsoft stuff), and Chrome Desktop), I'm convinced of a couple of things:-$200 is totally the sweet spot for Chromebooks.  This thing can do a lot and does it very fast, but it can't do everything.  Everyone should know that by now.  That's not a "con" for me.  I know this going in.  But at this price, what it does is incredible.-Waiting for the new Samsung Series means saving up another $100-200.  The new hardware looks intriguing (I'm generally a Samsung fan) and I bet it's very nice, but at $349-399 for the new units I'm starting to think Windows (the Asus Transformer Book T100, for example).  By the way, Windows 8's schizo Desktop/Metro is starting to grow on me.-$1100 for the Macbook Air was a goal until I returned to my profile and use case.  If I want a beautiful piece of hardware that I'll try to use for the next five years without much change, then maybe this is it.  But I'm also not sure I want to stash it in my backpack and crash the bike or bump it around.  I'd baby it too much.So thanks to the XP trade in, some passion from Puppylinuxworld on youtube, and reflection on my use, I took the plunge.  It's great!

Reviews.Title: Perfect for school
Reviews.Author: Tiffany
Reviews.Content: I'm typing this up on my Chromebook. It is very light weight and compact, so it's perfect for travel or taking to school. It's fast, thought it doesn't have much room for software. Documents can be made through Google docs and stored on cloud, so it's not a huge issue. It's kind of a bare-bones model and if that is all you need, then this is a good computer to use.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Laptop !! Beats any laptop if you are using it for internet
Reviews.Author: Raag
Reviews.Content: To start with this is a way better computer than any laptop including MAC if you are using it for internet purpose( Stream videos or youtube or just browse net)  Literally starts in 5 secs and battery 10 hours ....around 7 with video streaming!It has all the wonderful google apps for documents etc if i needBest part is i am using it for more than a month now and not a single time i had to restart... I watch tons of Amazon videos as i am prime member not a single time anything hangedAnother good thing to note is it does not heat up at all! no fan noise ....i have become a non paid salesman of this product!Excellent OS google!

Reviews.Title: Acer Chromebook
Reviews.Author: Janet Lee
Reviews.Content: Easy and simple.  I should have done this a while ago.  You continue to read the reviews and it just makes you nuts.  Just order it, try it, you'll love it.

Reviews.Title: Awesome
Reviews.Author: Randy Hillsgrove
Reviews.Content: I needed a new laptop and didn't want a heavy cumbersome device. I don't really like Windows with all of the updates and Macs are extremely expensive. I just needed something to surf with, maybe do a little online gaming, and edit some photos here and there. This device fit the bill to a T, super fast boot up. Extremely light and portable, zero heat on my lap. I've watched tv on it without issue, watched movies, listened to live radio. It really is an awesome system! I highly recommend it for those looking for an easy device to use and carry around. All kinds of apps to use.

Reviews.Title: Prefer this over a tablet
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I have two iPads, a 2013 Nexus 7, along with iPhones. I don't "need" another computer. But I do. Touchscreen devices are great for media consumption, but not for typing. Sure you can get keyboards for your iPad, but then you are just turning it into a laptop replacement, which is what the Chromebook is. Try balancing your iPad with case and keyboard on your couch armrest.I tried the HP Chromebook 11 at Best*** along with this Acer. Sure, I liked the screen better on the HP, but I didn't like the keyboard or the all white plastic. The Acer keyboard is better than the HP. I have a Lenovo laptop with their legendary keyboard and I still prefer the Acer keyboard over it.  I have fewer mistakes.The Acer has a better processor and longer battery life than the HP. The SD card slot is important if you want to load your camera's photos without a dongle.Streaming video is extremely quick on this Acer. There's some adjustments to get used to, like the Delete key is missing, (but you can hold the Alt key and press Backspace instead). Also, two-finger press of the trackpad will get you your "right click".

Reviews.Title: Fast, beautiful, intuitive. I love this thing!
Reviews.Author: Daniel E. Peck
Reviews.Content: This thing is awesome. It handles the web and OS wonderfully.  It's amazingly fast.  I was blown away. Beautiful stuff! Love the HDMI port. I can remote desktop to my other machines.  And I hear this thing is going to be running Windows apps thanks to a partnership with VMWare soon.  Epic!

Reviews.Title: So far it works great
Reviews.Author: Greasyregs "Greasyregs"
Reviews.Content: I've read so many reviews on the Chromebook and finally decided on the Acer.  I use it as a casual alternative to browsing and reading my email on my smartphone (screen too small) or my Samsung Tablet 7.0 (nice but I prefer a keyboard sometimes).  This will not replace my Lenovo laptop for business travel but it seems to be perfect for pleasure travel and just around the house when I don't want to get on my desktop and pull out my laptop.Fires up quickly, easy to use if you are a chrome browser user, and great battery life (so far around 7 hours!).  I started using the chromebook with a mouse but now am finding the I can do about everything using the touchpad.  It just takes a little time to figure out all the ways to replicate the mouse actions.  More of my computer usage is with Google Drive so document creation, editing and storage is not an issue.I suspect I would have been happy with the HP or the Samsung also but this Acer works fine for my needs.  And the price is right.

Reviews.Title: Growing to love it
Reviews.Author: Camba Reader
Reviews.Content: I am a daily Mac and Windows user, but I love this thing. It is so snappy: from instant on to loading web pages, this thing is awesome. There is a learning curve to figure out what I can do offline, but I am pretty comfortable 10 days into it. Paired with a Chromecast, it is awesome. I have used it for simple and fast photo edits (Pixlr touch ups). I use snagit for screen captures, and Biblia.com to access my Logos library of books (online only - but much simpler to use than the Logos software).I changed the settings for the trackpad to "australian" and now it mimics my Mac magic trackpad for scrolling up and down a page. With the Kindle extension, I am sending pages to my Kindle.Overall, it's great.

Reviews.Title: great value
Reviews.Author: Tod Harter
Reviews.Content: This is a great laptop to run Linux on, quite inexpensive for what you get. I'm traveling and it is great to have a small lightweight machine with sufficient power and ram to run a modern operating system and applications. It works well with ChromeOS as well if you only need web-based services. Acer has done a great job with the C720s, I think they're pretty much best-in-class for this type of machine.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Value!
Reviews.Author: Sac7000
Reviews.Content: Ok I'm not new to computers, PC's, Macs, iOS tablets (iPad) etc.,  Boots up in under 10 seconds, learning time is very short (hey, it's simple!) Keyboard is excellent, not backlit but come on turn your lamp on! It's lightweight and has a excellent battery life. Perfect for shopping, email, facebook, twitter and more. Bought one for my daughter and myself, we both love it and the best part is it's under $200 and very fast! Thank you Goggle chrome and Acer, you guys rock!Would I buy again? Yes!Would I recommend to a first time buyer? Yes!

Reviews.Title: The Perfect Computer
Reviews.Author: nolabola
Reviews.Content: I completely love this purchase.  I've been a Mac user for years and shy away from Windows machines.  I no longer use our Mac.  This meets all my needs.  The suite of Google Docs apps is evolved enough at this point that they provide everything you need.  I'm a periodicals librarian and do a lot of database work, and for nearly all my need Google Sheets works great.I get all day battery life no problem (8+ hours) and don't have to carry my charger around.  The screen is completely serviceable.  It's not my media machine and I wouldn't want to watch a movie on it, but for general use it's great.  Hangouts works really well.A note on dual booting with Linux.  I installed Ubuntu the day after I got it.  It worked fine, but there isn't enough stock memory to make it viable.  I ordered this drive (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00EZ2E8LQ/ref=oh_details_o00_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc;=1) which will fit and provide 64gb of storage.  Once I install that, it should run Linux without storage space issues.The only negative (and it's really minor) is that you can't upgrade the RAM.  Apparently it's soldered to the board.  It's not an issue, as the laptop is really snappy as is.

Reviews.Title: Great little device
Reviews.Author: Sir Isaac Newton
Reviews.Content: I am currently using this Chromebook to type this review and I couldn't be happier with the thing.  For $200 it is a little pricey because you can put down a little extra and buy a fully capable Windows laptop for around $300, but if you can find this on sale it is well worth it.  95% of what I do on a home laptop device is web based, so I knew going into it that this is not a full fledged laptop device.  For basic web surfing, it is top notch.  I have yet to see it bog down even with 10 tabs open.  There are several apps that make it more useful as well.  Battery life is also phenomenal!  I highly recommend for basic web use.

Reviews.Title: Great Machine, Blazing fast, But
Reviews.Author: Ameer Saib
Reviews.Content: The Chromebook works well and is amazingly fast, boot-up is under 10 sec. The battery last a long time. I like a lot of the chrome apps, and given time, I can see people breaking free of the Microsoft addiction. The only complaint thus far is the touch-pad which doesn't have a right and left buttons, making it sometimes difficult when making selections; a mouse is a must with this device.

Reviews.Title: Works Like A Dream
Reviews.Author: Patrick Northcraft
Reviews.Content: I'll keep this short and sweet, as there are plenty of well written and long reviews here already, which I did read before buying (as I never used a Chromebook before) and I would recommend you do as well.  Simply put, I bought this because I am currently a college student and I have a Lenovo G780 17" laptop as a desktop replacement in my dorm.  It was a little too big for me to lug around to my classes everyday, so I took a gamble and purchased this as a replacement.  There are apps for almost everything.  If you need to use Office, use SkyDrive and you can make Word, Excel, and PowerPoint online for free.  I strongly recommend this product.  The screen is very clear, the battery lasts very long, and the touchpad is pretty responsive.  The only design issue I have with it is that the speakers are on the bottom of the device, but that's just me.  The sound it still good, just not great when I sit it on my lap, as my leg absorbs the sound.  Overall, I do not regret buying this, and I would definitely buy it again.  It's a great deal.

Reviews.Title: good little computer
Reviews.Author: David Rider
Reviews.Content: good little computer. If all you need is to get online...do some research or shopping. This is perfect. Perfect for class and homework too...not to big and bulky. Gets the job done...note: Does not have a disk drive.

Reviews.Title: Great but beware
Reviews.Author: J. Kirby
Reviews.Content: If my screen didn't have a burned horizontal line that started after having it on the first time, it would get 5 stars, however I sent my first one back for a replacement, and the second one has done the exact same thing.  I read that most of the problems these have is the screen.  The screen is great out of the box, turn the thing on, then within a couple of hours this line appears, and then stays there even after the device is off.  Its been growing for the past two days, so this will be the second one to send back, and hopefully the third one does not have that problem.  As for speed, its pretty darn quick, can operate multiple windows open with no lag, nice feeling keyboard.  I really love this device and want one that does not have a defective screen.I would appreciate it if Acer would message me about this.

Reviews.Title: Excellent mini laptop
Reviews.Author: Elizabeth Propst
Reviews.Content: Does everything I need, nice to have a keyboard not a touch screen. Very fast and easy to use. Light, holds a charge a long time. Easy accurate touch pad.

Reviews.Title: Its great
Reviews.Author: pedro
Reviews.Content: I never realized how limited my use of computers was until I got the chromebook.But this may very well be the only computer I use from now on.It has google docs, internet and a webcam.And if I run out of space I can just use google drive.I don't even need to download videos or music, since I get it streamed online anyways.And all for the low price of 199.Also, no viruses.I was hesitant at first because the acer netbooks I got in the past were of low quality,but it seems that acer has stepped up its game.

Reviews.Title: Fast, basic computing
Reviews.Author: gesiferd
Reviews.Content: I purchased this laptop with the intention that it be a compact, low-maintenance option for mobile computing when a keyboard is needed.  It has more than met my expectations.  The screen is adequate, the keyboard reasonably comfortable and the operation trouble-free.  The keyboard half of the clamshell is slightly convex and the space bar deposits a light, easily-removed mark on the screen if I carry the laptop in a backpack and it's compressed a bit while traveling.  I'll be getting a small microfiber cloth to cover the keyboard when the laptop's closed, which should remedy that issue.  If you go in with your eyes open, realizing that there will be some applications that you can't run on Chrome OS and being willing to find substitutes, I believe you'll be pleased with this machine.  The price is great, especially as a refurb!

Reviews.Title: No, you are not stuck with the ChromeOS!!
Reviews.Author: carl801 "Old soldier"
Reviews.Content: I have been looking for years for a thin, light laptop computer that does not have Windows on it.  I object to paying the Gates tax only to immediately trash Windows and load Ubuntu.  This, finally, is that machine.  It took me all of an hour to find, download, and install Ubuntu 14.04 , which worked flawlessly out of the box.  Wireless, touchpad, networking, power management, the lot just work.  I currently have it set up to dual boot with ChromeOS, but I was so disappointed with the limitations of that operating system that I can't foresee using it again.  The machine is zippy and I feel no need for more than the 2GB of on-board memory.  However, now that I have a real operating system on it, 16GB is not nearly enough room, so I've ordered the MyDigitalSSD M.2 NGFF M2 64 GB SSD.So now I have what I wanted: a thin, light, capable laptop running my OS of choice, and I didn't have to pay for Windows in order to do it.  My thanks to Acer for building the machine, to Google for making open source ChromeOS free, and to Ubuntu and Canonical for making their OS so much better than Windows.

Reviews.Title: YES
Reviews.Author: Waleed Khan
Reviews.Content: Yes, yes, yes. $200 well spent, no regrets. This basically fits all my needs. When I announced I had bought a chromebook a few of my friends were disgusted. One said that "all it does is run the internet" and another said "they break in no time". To the second guy, I'm assuming he was talking about earlier chromebooks which I heard broke very easily. Everything I heard about this one before buying it said that it was much sturdier and did not break easily. To the first guy, I said well, that's all I really need.I really needed a new laptop and as a high school student my priority was speed, lightweight, thinness, efficiency, and for it to look nice. So I started looking into chromebooks and decided that this pretty much met those needs. I'm not really a hardcore gamer, and if I really need to play computer games there's always other laptops in my home to use. I love google chrome and chrome applications for their simplicity and ease. This gave me all that without other distractions. No need to worry about antivirus, no constant update reminders, no snail-pace start up, no overheating. Just so convenient. Obviously there are drawbacks of not being able to do all that you might be able to do with a traditional laptop but I'm willing to look past that. With my high school/artist's budget I don't really expect to make much and so don't really expect to be getting some high tech piece of machinery that works to perfection.The only problem I personally face is that my WiFi connection can be pretty s***ty, but that's not the chromebook's fault. Really, if my WiFi was out while I was on my old laptop I would pretty much have nothing to do except wait for it to come back. So why waste 300 extra bucks on something over priced and over large that I won't even use when I could have this for a much better price? Another thing I had to get accustomed to was the small size. I was expecting something a bit larger and I felt a little disappointed initially when I saw it, but I got over it pretty fast. Now when I use my old laptop or another "regular" laptop, it feels ridiculously large and awkward. This computer takes everything I need and gets rid of everything unnecessary and makes my life so much simpler. DEFINITELY recommend it to anyone who's primary concern with a laptop is the internet. 5/5 for me, thank you so much Google.

Reviews.Title: Good for what you pay
Reviews.Author: dclark
Reviews.Content: I bought this little device with the full intention of installing and primarily using linux. After some frustrating experiences with the trackpad (and as I was going out of town for a week) I decided to revert to Chrome OS just to have something to browse the web with during my trip. For doing just that, the machine is great, and works nearly flawlessly. Long battery life, quick and responsive, and quiet and cool. However, those benefits are also its drawbacks. If you plan to do any serious work, life gets difficult quickly. It's simply not made for those purposes. I eventually fixed all the issues I had with my linux installation, but still use Chrome sometimes. With linux the machine is great, and works just as a small laptop would.Chrome OS is the real limitation here, but for what many internet users do, I think this device is more than capable of meeting expectations. I would feel comfortable giving this to my mother, or a younger person as their own computer, knowing that they cannot really mess it up, nor would they be confused by the device (navigation is much more logical than say, Windows 8). Unless you fall into one of the previous categories, and even then it is unlikely, I would not recommend this as a main computer. As a portable device, that is less annoying to use for surfing the web than a smart phone, it does well.The main reason for docking a star is the build quality. Though the machine is thin and light, Mostly plastic casing makes the computer feel more like a toy than nicer laptops. In addition, the screen has poor viewing angles and the color is lackluster. Trackpad is small and lacks well defined button areas, sort of an attempt to recreate the apple trackpad gone wrong. I find myself tapping by not pressing down, but tapping on the trackpad, which I've never done until now. Due to the smallness of the laptop as a whole, the keyboard is not the standard size and lacks some of the more conventional keys (such as the delete key, which is more frustrating than you'd think). Overall, it was only $229, which makes up for many of the drawbacks. Someone who is looking for a very portable mobile web browsing unit, or someone who is a bit (just a bit, it's really not that hard) more savvy who is willing to install linux, would benefit greatly from this device. It's reasonably priced and does what is advertised, I'm satisfied.

Reviews.Title: Exceeded my expectations.....
Reviews.Author: Hugh D. Hudgens
Reviews.Content: The Acer 720 arrived in a couple of days. It was neat and clean. Start up was almost instant. It took me a few minutes to navigate my way around. A few days to get things how I like them. Since then everything has been wonderful. This machine is super fast and light weight. From dead battery to full charge is only 60 to 90 minutes. I would recommend this laptop to anyone as a second machine and a first machine to many. Do a little research. Make sure to get the Celeron processor. It flies. Enjoy surfing.

Reviews.Title: I love my Acer Chromebook!
Reviews.Author: Toni L.
Reviews.Content: This notebook is easy to use and very light. The speakers are great! I love the simplicity. The battery last for a very long time on a full charge.

Reviews.Title: Nice, inexpensive laptop for Linux
Reviews.Author: Phil Lembo
Reviews.Content: This is a nice, inexpensive piece of hardware. I got one used from an Amazon vendor.After running ChomeOS on it for over a month finally installed Fedora Linux 20 with the stock Gnome desktop. Although my model (C720-2802) only has 2G (of non-upgradable) RAM, Fedora with Gnome 3 fits nicely. Did upgrade the shipping 16G SSD to 64G using a part from another Amazon vendor. That leaves plenty of room for installing additional apps and almost 20G of space for files. Now I can use my Chromebook to makes calls over Skype! But seriously, if you're comfortable experimenting with computer hardware and not afraid of open source you're going to love this model. There are tons of blog posts and technical wiki articles on the Internet explaining how to turn this into a really useful machine.

Reviews.Title: This laptop serves your basic needs
Reviews.Author: Dave
Reviews.Content: This laptop is basically a glorified tablet BUT you get more bang for your buck.The ChromeBook OS is so simple that Honey Boo Boo can operate it with her eyes closed and her mouth full of Faygo. The App store has a whole array of apps for you to do basic functions as you would with any laptop. You wanna type up something? WE GOT AN APP FOR THAT. You wanna make slides? WE GOT AN APP FOR THAT. No, you cannot install software of any sort but with all the app options, why would you? Unless you're a hardcore Skype-r or whatever you kids do to make yourselves feel important, the software is great.The screen is as bright as Stephen Hawking but consumes power like an Ethiopian. Great resolution AND 8.5 hours of battery life?! Stop the madness. I did notice a tad of overheating when I lay the base of the laptop on a flat surface as I was doing some work, but you shouldn't do that anyways and if you blame the manufacturer for that design flaw, then I suggest you don't procreate.All I needed was a laptop to do school work on and watch Netflix. For 200 bucks, you cant go wrong. This little thing is fast, concise, and all around easy to use. I recommend this laptop to anyone who needs to type up things in a Starbucks while wearing his dumb glasses with hard part hair, record a naked greeting for your grandmother on her 87 birthday, or even do a power point presentation on how much you hate power point presentations. THIS LAPTOP IS FOR YOOOOU.

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: Chuck Harold
Reviews.Content: For the price, this computer is awesome! Very portable, good battery life, works just as expected. Highly recommended, especially if all you do is online!

Reviews.Title: Excellent value, good performance
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: 15 or 20 years ago, my parents' employers decided to deploy thin clients throughout their school district.  I was appalled.  Networks being what they were, I shuddered to think of the lag they'd experience when all the teachers tried to access their accounts simultaneously, and how everything would come to a screeching halt the moment the district servers went down.My, how recent developments have changed my opinion.This was purchased to replace a poorly aging Windows XP laptop which my kids used for schoolwork.  It's fantastic.  I've always been wary of anything that won't let me save anything I want locally, but the development and steady improvement of cloud services has done a lot to alleviate that concern and the kids, who've grown up with mobile devices that have limited storage space, have no qualms with apps that both reside and save their data to Google drive.  It's not a desktop replacement, it's not a home entertainment/gaming system, and it won't allow you to hack into  WOPR to play a game of global thermonuclear war, but it'll let you write a report, email it to your mom to be proofread, video chat with said mom to go over the finer nuances of grammar, print it to a networked printer, save it to Google Drive, email it to your teacher, and then settle in for some well-deserved time on Club Penguin.

Reviews.Title: Just WOW!!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Last week I bought a refurb unit direct from Acer ($150) and the unit arrived today. I bought this for my dad since he's a senior and the old Windows Vista is getting to be a real pain for him to work with. I originally purchased a Samsung Chromebook (when it was first introduced) for him but found out the printing mechanism wasn't quite there. So I've been using this Acer Chromebook tonight and it's simply a joy to use!My setup with the unit is paired with my Google CloudPrint enabled printer, Epson WorkForce 845. Set up was easy enough. Since this unit is for my dad, I'm going to get him a low-end Epson Expression XP-410. It's only $69 on Amazon and it's a steal! One thing my dad does with his current printer is using it to scan documents and feed directly to his email. I don't think the Epson does it automatically but as a workaround, he could scan the doc onto a SD card or thumb drive, then un-mount it and stick it in the Chromebook. Not as direct but the process is quite straight forward. It shouldn't be a problem for him, albeit he's 83. :-) Go dad!!I also tested the VPN connection and it works flawlessly. I have a VPN service so I could watch BBC programs via the iPlayer. Previously I've been using my Nexus 7 and hooking that up to my TV via a SlimPort connection. It's a bit of a pain but using the Chromebook, the process is much more reliable. Bluetooth works as expected. I'm very happy with how far Chromebook has come, therefore I'll be getting my own unit next week! I was planning on getting the 32GB unit but decided not to since I ordered a 64GB SSD replacement. It's only $50+ and I think it's worth it. Was thinking about the 128GB but since I'll be utilizing Google Drive (with a free 100GB for 2 years); I think 64GB is plenty; at least for now.What needs to improve? Not so much the hardware but I wish the OS has the ability to save web pages on the Shelf, or in a folder or some sort. There's a workaround on doing that but the process isn't as simple. Certain keys are missing from a traditional keyboard standpoint, but I'll adjust. If you miss your Function Keys, there's a way that you can set up your keyboard to toggle them back. It feels a bit 'odd' not being able to save anything on the 'desktop'. It's different and I think I'm going to like it, a lot!Thanks for reading.UPDATE: I just read about where the Epson Connect website has an option where you could scan directly to your Google Drive. Su-weeet!

Reviews.Title: One of the best chromebooks that happens to also be the cheapest one
Reviews.Author: J. Limandri
Reviews.Content: This is is one of the best chromebooks and I have used almost all of them.  The Dell chromebook 11 and the Toshiba 13.3 may be slightly better, but its close.  But if you only have $200 to spend on a laptop I would just get the c720 now.

Reviews.Title: Does what I expected
Reviews.Author: Travis Carter
Reviews.Content: As long as you know it's Google Apps only you'll like it. I thought it would be too small but it's not bad. Can't beat the price.

Reviews.Title: Nice little machine
Reviews.Author: Kimberly Insco
Reviews.Content: This does exactly what I need it to do for under half the price of a traditional laptop. The only reasons I don't rate this as 5 stars is the touchpad and I thought I was getting an ssd card but I did not receive one with my order. In all fairness though how many touchpads are good? This is why God created the cute furry rodent called a mouse.

Reviews.Title: Easy and light
Reviews.Author: Franky
Reviews.Content: This is the best travel computer that I have owned; it does everything I need and the price cannot  be beat.

Reviews.Title: Great travel machine, excellent battery life
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I'm typing this review on my chromebook.  I love it.  It's featherlight (well not really but it's very light), it's compact and it's fast.  I was worried about keyboard size as I'm a pretty big guy (6'3") and have big hands but it feels just fine to me.  Best things about it are the boot up time (it really is about 7 seconds, 3 if it's just waking up from sleep) and the battery life which can stretch all day if I'm only using it for 30 minutes at a time here and there.  I think I last charged this last night and 24 hours later, I still have 60% left since I only used it twice this morning.It's not a full laptop so if you get it to do productivity things (spreadsheets and documents) you probably won't like it.  But if you want something to travel with that will do everything you need without leaving a huge dent in your wallet if something happens to it, this is the machine.  Really happy with the purchase, highly recommend.

Reviews.Title: Perfect alternative to a tablet with a keyboard
Reviews.Author: Kim Haman
Reviews.Content: He loves it.  It is lightweight, does what it says it does.  If you need a computer for just browsing the web (as he does) it does the job.  Is super fast, lightweight, works great.  We couldn't be happier with this purchase, it's his current favorite toy ;)

Reviews.Title: Impressive piece
Reviews.Author: Mhoward8
Reviews.Content: This is a surprisingly impressive unit based on the price. The specs are obviously not going to be up there with the specialized models and their 3rdand RAM are great for light, office work.The performance is also smooth despite its disadvantage in hardware and the picture quality is adequate, considering. The best feature though is the Chrome OS, which uses up very little memory despite dishing out considerable power. For a cheap laptop, you’re getting a lot of value.gen I series processors, but the battery life, memory

Reviews.Title: i love it
Reviews.Author: cam
Reviews.Content: I must admit at first i was a little skeptical after using windows for so long but this has super exceeded my expectations by far. The only thing cheap about it is the price. Dont take my word for it try it yourself. Speed, durability, no clutter, perfect size, not to small not to big and it has flash already installed which is a major plus. Im officially team chrome :)

Reviews.Title: Fantastic little computer.
Reviews.Author: Shannon Caissie
Reviews.Content: For almost four and a half years, I've been using an Acer Aspire One netbook running Windows XP, so it would have been nearly impossible to get a new computer that DOESN'T run better, faster, longer, and quieter.Things I like:-this thing cost over $100 less than my old netbook, has a bigger screen, and is lighter and thinner-using 3 fingers on the trackpad to switch between tabs-although there's no dedicated monitor on/off button, you can turn the screen brightness down to the point of the screen going black-it boots up so fast I barely notice a difference between it turning on and it coming out of sleep mode-I've actually used every key on the keyboard-I can pick it up by one corner and I don't hear a cracking sound.Things I don't like:-there's no Delete key which I had gotten into the habit of using a lot when my old netbook's backspace key started becoming unreliable, instead there's "alt+backspace" and the power button is where the Delete key used to be on my netbook so I've almost put the computer into sleep mode a couple times-there's no number pad, not even a "fn +" number pad like on my old netbook-when the fan does turn on, it tends to turn on for like one second, cool down enough to turn off, and repeat every two seconds for a while, but I'm pretty sure that's not terribly abnormal for a laptop. It's not loud, it's just annoying when it keeps turning on and off.Things I am ambivalent towards and simply have to get used to:-I have turned this thing on like once since I got it because it turns itself on/wakes itself up every time you open the lid if it possibly can. That includes the very first time you plug it in which startled me a little.-there's not much available in terms of customization/options for stuff like when it sleeps/turns off the monitor, but there's not much I've felt the need to change in the first place-the keyboard labels are in all lowercase-I can't use the NotScripts chrome extension because I can't get into the program files to set the password, but seeing as the Chrome OS is supposed to be nearly immune to viruses I probably don't need to worry-there are no function keys, but the only ones I used were for refreshing and fullscreen, and there are keys for those-the caps lock key was replaced with a "Search" key but one of the customization options they do give you is the ability to change it back to a caps lock key so naturally I switched it right back-when I press the keys, they don't go down very far so I kept feeling like the keystroke couldn't possibly have registered properlyIf you spend a lot of time online and/or writing, a Chromebook is probably right for you.If you're into gaming, digital art, etc., you're better off getting a more conventional computer.

Reviews.Title: Great all doer
Reviews.Author: Emmanuel V.
Reviews.Content: Fast, fluid, great battery life and hassle free updates. A must buy for anyone looking for a great laptop at a great price

Reviews.Title: Great for school
Reviews.Author: Bubble Blower
Reviews.Content: Bought these for my 9th grade twins and they are working good. Internet is fast, battery life is good and Google docs has everything my children need for school automatically saved on Google Drive. If I could ask for one improvement it would be to simplify printing. My printer is not Google Cloud Print ready so setting up to print has been a little difficult.

Reviews.Title: Great cheap laptop.
Reviews.Author: OG
Reviews.Content: My main laptop is the Macbook Air 13", but I recently got the C720 as a cheap alternative to take with me on short business trips, while I leave the MBA at home for my wife to use. It is very good for the price and the touchpad is surprising decent. However, one issue that has come up is a high pitched sound coming from the laptop. This is only audible in quiet rooms but it is there. More than a few people have experienced this issue and have posted about it online. I will probably bring it into a store for exchange but others haven't had any luck. If it were not for this issue, I'd give it 5 stars.

Reviews.Title: Everything I expected
Reviews.Author: Brendan Stringer
